revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=July 2016}} {{featured article}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name=No. 1 Squadron RAAF |image=[[File:1SqnRAAFCrest.png|120px|alt=Crest of 1 Squadron, Royal Australian Air Force, featuring a diving kookaburra before the Jerusalem cross, and the motto "Videmus Agamus"]] |caption=No. 1 Squadron's crest |dates= 1916–19
1925–42
1943–46
1948–current |country= Australia |allegiance= |branch= [[Royal Australian Air Force]] |type= |role= Air-to-air/air-to-surface combat |size= |command_structure=[[No. 82 Wing RAAF|No. 82 Wing]] |garrison=[[RAAF Base Amberley]] |nickname="Fighting First" |patron= |motto=''Videmus agamus''
{{nowrap|({{lang-la|"We Seek and We Strike"}})}} |colors= |colors_label= |march= |mascot= |battles=World War I
World War II
[[Malayan Emergency]]
{{nowrap|[[2014 military intervention against the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Military intervention against ISIL]]}} |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours=[[Sinai and Palestine Campaign|Egypt 1915–1917]] {{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_10834.asp|title=1 Squadron AFC|publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]]|accessdate=12 September 2014}}
[[Sinai and Palestine Campaign|Palestine 1917–1918]]
[[Malayan Emergency|Malaya 1948–1960]] {{cite news|last=Stackpool|first=Andrew|author2=Solomou, Bill |title=New battle honours unveiled|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?iid=47220&xml=defencenews_airforce.xml&startpage=4|accessdate=14 September 2014|newspaper=[[Air Force (newspaper)|Air Force]]|date=14 April 2011|pages=4–5}} |commander1=[[Richard Williams (RAAF officer)|Richard Williams]] (1917–18)
[[Harry Cobby]] (1925–26)
[[Raymond Brownell]] (1926–28)
[[Frank Lukis]] (1930, 1932–34)
[[Frank Bladin]] (1934–35)
[[Alan Charlesworth]] (1936–39)
[[Allan Walters]] (1940–41)
[[Errol McCormack]] (1978–79) |commander1_label=Notable {{nowrap|commanders RAAF Historical Section, ''Bomber Units'', pp. 5–6}} |notable_commanders= |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label= |aircraft_attack=[[Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet|F/A-18F Super Hornet]] |aircraft_bomber= |aircraft_electronic= |aircraft_recon= |aircraft_trainer= }} '''No. 1 Squadron''' is a [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) squadron headquartered at [[RAAF Base Amberley]], Queensland. Controlled by [[No. 82 Wing RAAF|No. 82 Wing]], it is equipped with [[Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet|Boeing F/A-18F Super Hornet]] multi-role fighters. The squadron was formed under the [[Australian Flying Corps]] in 1916 and saw action in the [[Sinai and Palestine Campaign]]s during World War I. It flew obsolete [[Royal Aircraft Factory B.E.2]]s, B.E.12s, [[Martinsyde G.100]]s and G.102s, as well as [[Airco DH.6]]s, [[Bristol Scout]]s and [[Nieuport 17]]s, before re-equipping with the [[Royal Aircraft Factory R.E.8|R.E.8]] in October 1917 and finally the [[Bristol F.2 Fighter|Bristol Fighter]] in December. Its commanding officer in 1917–18 was Major [[Richard Williams (RAAF officer)|Richard Williams]], later known as the "Father of the RAAF". Disbanded in 1919, No. 1 Squadron was re-formed on paper as part of the RAAF in 1922, and re-established as an operational unit three years later. During World War II, the squadron flew [[Lockheed Hudson]] bombers in the [[Malayan Campaign|Malayan]] and [[Dutch East Indies campaign]]s, suffering severe losses before being reduced to [[En cadre|cadre]] in 1942. It was re-formed with [[Bristol Beaufort]]s the following year, and re-equipped with [[de Havilland Mosquito]]s in 1945 for further operations in the Dutch East Indies. Reduced to cadre once more after the war ended, No. 1 Squadron was re-established at Amberley in 1948 as an [[Avro Lincoln]] heavy bomber unit. From 1950 to 1958 it was based in Singapore, flying missions during the [[Malayan Emergency]], where it bore the brunt of the Commonwealth air campaign against communist guerillas. When it returned to Australia it re-equipped with [[English Electric Canberra]] jet bombers. It operated [[McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II|McDonnell Douglas F-4E Phantom]]s from 1970 to 1973, as a stop-gap pending delivery of the [[General Dynamics F-111C]] swing-wing bomber. The F-111 remained in service for 37 years until replaced by the Super Hornet in 2010. From September 2014 to March 2015, a detachment of Super Hornets was deployed to the Middle East as part of [[Operation Okra|Australia's contribution]] to the [[2014 military intervention against the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|military intervention against ISIL]]. ==Role and equipment== [[File:Cockpit of a RAAF FA-18F.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|F/A-18F Super Hornet of No. 1 Squadron, 2013|alt= Forward section of military jet on an airfield, with open canopy and two crewmen seated in the cockpit]] No. 1 Squadron is located at [[RAAF Base Amberley]], Queensland, and controlled by [[No. 82 Wing RAAF|No. 82 Wing]], which is part of [[Air Combat Group RAAF|Air Combat Group]]. Its mission responsibilities include air-to-air and air-to-surface combat.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Air-Combat-Group/No.-82-Wing/No.-1-Squadron/?RAAF-LGjodmvBnUG6tbsKAUbGu4lNy07+Rf7x|title=No. 1 Squadron|publisher=[[Royal Australian Air Force]]|accessdate=30 April 2014}} The squadron is nicknamed the "Fighting First".{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Air-Combat-Group/No.-82-Wing/No.-1-Squadron/?RAAF-LGjodmvBnUG6tbsKAUbGu4lNy07+Rf7x|title=No. 1 Squadron history|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=12 March 2014}} The [[blazon]] of its crest is "the Australian [[Kookaburra]] in a diving position superimposed on the [[Jerusalem cross|cross of Jerusalem]]", which symbolises the [[Victoria Cross]]-winning action of No. 1 Squadron pilot [[Frank McNamara (VC)|Frank McNamara]] in [[Sinai and Palestine Campaign|Palestine]] during World War I. The unit motto is ''Videmus Agamus'' (''"We see and we strike"'').{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Air Force (newspaper)|RAAF News]]|title=Crests tell history|date=December 1961|page=6}} The squadron operates [[Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet|Boeing F/A-18F Super Hornet]] multi-role fighters, the first of which entered service in March 2010. Nicknamed the "Rhino", its missions include [[air superiority]], fighter escort, land strike, maritime strike, [[close air support]], and [[reconnaissance]].{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?xml=defencenews_airforce.xml&iid=55561&startpage=2|last=Smith|first=Skye|title=Fanfare for Rhinos|magazine=Air Force |date=27 October 2011|page=23|accessdate=30 April 2014}} The Super Hornet is larger than the "classic" [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet]] operated by the RAAF, carries more [[Aircraft ordnance|ordnance]], and has a greater fuel capacity. It is fitted with a [[20 mm caliber|20 mm cannon]] and can be armed with air-to-air and anti-shipping missiles, as well as a variety of air-to-ground bombs and missiles.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/Technology/Aircraft/Super-Hornet/?RAAF-4dRvdvKuGAokY31UEml0P+KGoMiO8n/o|title=F/A-18F Super Hornet|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=30 April 2014}} Flown by a crew of two, a pilot and an air combat officer (ACO), it is capable of engaging targets in the air and on the surface simultaneously.{{cite journal|last=Wilson|first= Stewart (ed.) |title=Royal Australian Air Force 1921–2011|work=Aero Australia Special Edition|publisher=Chevron|location=St Leonards, New South Wales|page=104}}McPhedran, ''Air Force'', p. 356 It can be [[aerial refueling|refuelled in flight]] by the RAAF's [[Airbus A330 MRTT|Airbus KC-30A Multi Role Tanker Transports]].{{cite magazine|title=RAAF's KC-30 service ready|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2013/02/raafs-kc-30-service-ready/|accessdate=28 April 2014|magazine=[[Australian Aviation (magazine)|Australian Aviation]]|date=26 February 2013}} The Super Hornets are serviced at the operating level by No. 1 Squadron technical staff; heavier maintenance is conducted by [[Boeing Australia|Boeing Defence Australia]] and other contractors.{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?xml=defencenews_airforce.xml&iid=34741&startpage=12|last=Smith|first=Skye|title=Can't wait to get started|magazine=Air Force|date=1 April 2010|page=13|accessdate=30 April 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.asiapacificdefencereporter.com/articles/10/Super-Hornets-Industry-Support-for-the-RAAFs-Rhinos|title=Super Hornets: industry support for the RAAF's Rhinos|work=Asia-Pacific Defence Reporter|date=10 February 2010|accessdate=30 April 2014}} ==History== ===World War I=== No. 1 Squadron was established as a unit of the [[Australian Flying Corps]] (AFC) at [[RAAF Williams|Point Cook]], Victoria, in January 1916 under the command of [[Lieutenant Colonel]] E.H. Reynolds.Eather, ''Flying Squadrons'', pp. 8–9 With a complement of 28 officers, 195 airmen, no aircraft and little training, it sailed for Egypt in mid-March 1916, arriving at [[Suez]] a month later.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', pp. 24, 56–57 There it came under the control of the [[No. 5 Wing RAF|5th Wing]] of the [[Royal Flying Corps]] (RFC).Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', p. 57 After training in England and Egypt, the unit was declared operational at its new headquarters in [[Heliopolis (Cairo suburb)|Heliopolis]] on 12 June, when it took over aircraft belonging to [[No. 17 Squadron RAF|No. 17 Squadron RFC]]. Its three [[Flight (military unit)|flights]] were, however, operating in isolation at different bases in the [[Sinai Desert]], and the squadron did not reunite until December.RAAF Historical Section, ''Bomber Units'', pp. 1–2Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', pp. 35–36 Flying primitive and poorly armed [[Royal Aircraft Factory B.E.2]] two-seat biplanes, its primary roles during this period of the [[Sinai and Palestine Campaign|Sinai Campaign]] were reconnaissance—including aerial photography—and artillery spotting for the [[British Army]].Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', pp. 59–60 No. 1 Squadron pilots attached to [[No. 14 Squadron RAF|No. 14 Squadron RFC]] took part in the [[Battle of Romani]] in July and August.Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', p. 40Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', pp. 63–64 In September and October, B and C Flights, led by Captains [[Oswald Watt]] and [[Richard Williams (RAAF officer)|Richard Williams]] respectively, undertook bombing and reconnaissance missions in support of the [[Australian Light Horse]] in northern Sinai.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', pp. 61–62, 68–70 [[File:A05340WilliamsMcNamara.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Members of C Flight, No. 1 Squadron, including Lieutenant McNamara (left), Captain Williams (third from right) and Lieutenant Wackett (right), in front of a Martinsyde near the [[Suez Canal]], Egypt, 1917|alt=Full-length outdoor portrait of six men in military uniforms in front of a military biplane with a machine gun mounted on the upper wing]] On 12 September 1916, the British began to refer to No. 1 Squadron as [[No. 67 Squadron RAF|No. 67 (Australian) Squadron]] RFC. This practice continued until January 1918, when the unit officially became known as No. 1 Squadron AFC. The relationship between airmen and ground crew was less formal than in British units; squadron members recalled that "The CO is the only one who is ever called 'sir{{' "}} and that officers did not demand "saluting and standing to attention and all that rot".Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', p. 52 The unit received the first of several [[Martinsyde G.100]] single-seat fighters to augment the B.E.2s on 16 October; although considered obsolete, the "Tinsyde" was substantially faster than the B.E.2, and armed with forward-firing machine guns.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', p. 71 Shortly before the squadron took part in a bombing raid against [[Beersheba]] on 11 November, Lieutenant [[Lawrence Wackett]] managed to fix a machine gun to the top plane of one of the B.E.2s, using a mount he designed himself.Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', pp. 43–45 Each flight was also assigned a [[Bristol Scout]] beginning in December, but it too was obsolete and under-powered, and the squadron ceased operating the type within three months.Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', p. 47 Other older models issued to the unit included the [[Airco DH.6]], Martinsyde G.102 and [[Nieuport 17]]. On 17 December, the squadron's flights were finally brought together at one base, Mustabig.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', p. 75 March 1917 saw the heaviest bombing campaign carried out by the squadron to date; short of its regular {{convert|20|lb|kg|adj=on}} ordnance, the pilots improvised by dropping {{convert|6|inch|mm|adj=on}} [[howitzer]] shells on Turkish forces along the [[Gaza City|Gaza]]–Beersheba line.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', pp. 84–85 During one such mission on 20 March, Lieutenant [[Frank McNamara (VC)|Frank McNamara]] earned the [[Victoria Cross]] for landing his Martinsyde in the desert under enemy fire and rescuing a fellow pilot whose B.E.2 had been forced down.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', pp. 86–88 On 26 March, No. 1 Squadron took part in the [[First Battle of Gaza]]; it suffered its first combat death the next day, when one of its B.E.2s was attacked by a German [[Rumpler]].Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', pp. 88–89, 91–92 The unit participated in the [[Second Battle of Gaza]] on 19 April; like its predecessor, the attack was a failure for the Allies.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', pp. 93–94 Williams, later known as the "Father of the RAAF", assumed command of the squadron in May.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', p. 97Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 30 Two B.E.12s were delivered the same month; like the Martinsydes, they were armed with a forward-firing machine gun and employed as escorts for the B.E.2s.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', p. 98 By June, mechanical issues caused by hot summer weather and the threat from new German [[Albatros Flugzeugwerke|Albatros]] scouts were rendering the B.E.2s largely ineffective, and Williams urgently requested newer models.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', pp. 99–100 Modern aircraft were eventually delivered, first the [[Royal Aircraft Factory R.E.8]] in October, and then the [[Bristol F.2 Fighter]] in December. "Now for the first time," wrote Williams, "after 17 months in the field we had aircraft with which we could deal with our enemy in the air."{{cite magazine | last = Mordike | first = John | year = 2002 | title = General Sir Edmund Allenby's joint operations in Palestine, 1917–1918 | url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/rafcms/mediafiles/49896C98_1143_EC82_2E67619953626AC0.pdf|magazine= The Royal Air Force Air Power Review |page=18}} [[File:Ross Smith Bristol Fighter.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|Lieutenant Ross Smith (left) with a No. 1 Squadron Bristol Fighter, Palestine, February 1918 |alt=Two men in flying gear next to a military biplane]] No. 1 Squadron joined the [[No. 40 Wing RAF|40th (Army) Wing]] of the RFC's [[Palestine Brigade RAF|Palestine Brigade]] on 5 October 1917.Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', p. 64 On 22 and 24 November, the squadron bombed Bireh village during the [[Battle of Jerusalem (1917)|Battle of Jerusalem]].Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', p. 86 The first of its 29 confirmed aerial victories, over an Albatros, occurred on 3 January 1918. By month's end, its complement of aircraft included five B.E.2s, five Martinsydes, two R.E.8s, and nine Bristol Fighters.Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', p. 88 The squadron supported the [[Capture of Jericho]] in February 1918.Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', pp. 102–103Falls; Becke, ''Military Operations Egypt & Palestine from June 1917 to the End of the War'', Volume 2, Part I, p. 309 It carried out air raids and reconnoitred prior to the [[First Transjordan attack on Amman]] in March and prior to the [[Second Transjordan attack on Shunet Nimrin and Es Salt]] a month later; it also flew reconnaissance missions during the advance to and fighting near Es Salt and [[Jisr ed Damieh]].Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', pp. 95, 106–109, 113, 116–117 By the end of March, it was equipped with 18 Bristol Fighters, which had replaced all the other types. As well as undertaking offensive operations, the Bristol Fighters served in the photo-reconnaissance role. During the last week of April 1918, the squadron moved its base forward from Mejdel to a new aerodrome outside [[Ramla|Ramleh]].Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', p. 122 Williams relinquished command in June to take over 40th Wing.Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', p. 133 Beginning in August 1918, members of No. 1 Squadron, including one of its [[Flying ace|aces]], Lieutenant [[Ross Macpherson Smith|Ross Smith]], were attached to Colonel [[T.E. Lawrence]]'s Arab army to protect it against German bombing.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 13 In September, the squadron began operating a [[Handley Page Type O|Handley Page 0/100]], the only Allied heavy bomber in the Middle East and the only twin-engined aircraft flown by the AFC. That month it joined the Bristol Fighters in the final offensive of the Palestinian Campaign, the [[Battle of Megiddo (1918)|Battle of Armageddon]], inflicting what the [[Official History of Australia in the War of 1914–1918|Australian official history]] described as "wholesale destruction" on the Turkish [[Seventh Army (Ottoman Empire)|Seventh Army]].Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 13–14Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', pp. 151–152, 161 By October, the Bristol Fighters had moved forward from Ramleh to [[Haifa]] and by the middle of the month were required to patrol and reconnoitre an exceptionally wide area of country, sometimes between {{convert|500|and|600|mi|km}}, flying over [[Rayak (Riyaq)|Rayak]], [[Homs]], [[Beirut]], [[Tripoli]], [[Hama]], [[Aleppo]], [[Kilis|Killis]] and [[İskenderun|Alexandretta]]. They bombed the German aerodromes at Rayak, where 32 German machines had been either abandoned or burnt, on 2 October. On 19 October, the first German aircraft was seen in the air since fighting over [[Deraa]] in mid-September, just prior to the [[Battle of Sharon]]. Smith and another pilot forced a [[Deutsche Flugzeug-Werke|DFW]] two-seater to land, and destroyed it on the ground by firing a [[Flare gun|Very light]] into the aircraft after the German pilot and observer had moved to safety.Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', pp. 168–169Falls; Becke, ''Military Operations Egypt & Palestine from June 1917 to the End of the War '', Volume 2, Part II, p. 466 In the wake of the 31 October armistice with Turkey, the squadron relocated to Ramleh in December, and then in February 1919 to [[El-Qantarah el-Sharqiyya|Kantara]]. There its members were personally farewelled by General [[Edmund Allenby, 1st Viscount Allenby|Sir Edmund Allenby]], who congratulated them for achieving "absolute supremacy of the air ... a factor of paramount importance" to the Allied campaign.Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres'', p. 171 ===Inter-war years=== [[File:RAAF Airco DH.9a (AWM P02413.010).JPG|left|upright=1.2|thumb|Airco DH.9a at RAAF Point Cook, 1926|alt=Military biplane parked at an airfield with a crowd of spectators]] No. 1 Squadron returned to Australia on 5 March 1919, and was disbanded. In 1921, the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) was established as a separate branch of the military, and on 1 January 1922, the squadron was re-formed on paper.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 29 Its planned strength, approved by the Air Board in December 1921, was three officers and five airmen, operating four [[Airco DH.9]]s. Funding problems for the fledgling Air Force resulted in the disbandment on 1 July of No. 1 Squadron and other units established at the same time, their aircraft and personnel instead forming a single squadron of six flights under the control of [[No. 1 Flying Training School RAAF|No. 1 Flying Training School]] (No. 1 FTS) at Point Cook.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 42–43 No. 1 Squadron was reactivated as an operational unit of the RAAF reserve, known as the Citizen Air Force (CAF), at Point Cook on 1 July 1925.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', p. 226 Its commanding officer was Flight Lieutenant [[Harry Cobby]]. Like [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 Squadron]], formed the same day at Point Cook but transferred to [[RAAF Base Richmond|RAAF Richmond]], New South Wales, three weeks later, No. 1 Squadron was a multi-purpose or "composite" unit made up of three flights, each of which had a different role and comprised four aircraft: A Flight operated DH.9s for army cooperation, B Flight operated [[Royal Aircraft Factory S.E.5]] fighters, and C Flight operated [[Airco DH.9A|DH.9A]] bombers.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 186, 226 A third of the squadron's complement of 27 officers and 169 airmen was Permanent Air Force (PAF), and the rest CAF.RAAF Historical Section, ''Bomber Units'', pp. 2–3 No. 1 Squadron relocated from Point Cook to nearby [[RAAF Williams#RAAF Williams Laverton Base|RAAF Laverton]] on 1 January 1928.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 129, 131 The RAAF retired its S.E.5s the same year, and in 1929 took delivery of [[Westland Wapiti]] general-purpose aircraft to replace its DH.9s and DH.9As.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 176–178 Through the inter-war years, No. 1 Squadron undertook various tasks including civil aid, flood and bushfire relief, search and rescue, aerial surveys, and air show demonstrations.Barnes, ''The RAAF and the Flying Squadrons'', p. 9Eather, ''Flying Squadrons'', p. 19 In October 1930, a [[de Havilland DH.60 Moth]] attached to the unit conducted Australia's first crop-dusting operation, at the behest of the Victorian Forestry Commission.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', p. 377 [[File:No. 1 Squadron RAAF Demon (AWM P00448.130).JPG|right|upright=1.2|thumb|Hawker Demons of No. 1 Squadron at RAAF Laverton, August 1938|alt=Lineup of military biplanes at an airfield]] RAAF squadrons began adopting specialised roles in the early 1930s, No. 1 Squadron becoming No. 1 Single-Engined Bomber Squadron.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', p. 189 By November 1935 it was made up of two flights of newly delivered [[Hawker Demon]] fighter-bombers, and one of Wapitis.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 188, 190, 327 In December 1935 it was augmented by No. 1 FTS's Fighter Squadron and its six [[Bristol Bulldog]]s, which were redesignated fighter-bombers.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', p. 187No. 1 Squadron, ''Operations Record Book'' (1925–1946), pp. 88–89 [[No. 21 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 21]] and [[No. 22 Squadron RAAF|22 (Cadre) Squadrons]] were formed on 20 April 1936 at Laverton and Richmond, respectively, absorbing the CAF personnel of Nos. 1 and 3 Squadrons, which became PAF units. The same day, No. 1 Squadron was renamed No. 1 (Fighter Bomber) Squadron. This reorganisation temporarily denuded No. 1 Squadron of most of its aircraft, leaving only A Flight, with four Bulldogs and a Wapiti, in operation.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 187, 231–232No. 1 Squadron, ''Operations Record Book'' (1925–1946), pp. 98–100 The Wapiti was transferred to No. 1 FTS in July, and by the end of the month the squadron's complement of aircraft stood at four Bulldogs and one Moth.No. 1 Squadron, ''Operations Record Book'' (1925–1946), p. 107 No. 1 Squadron began receiving new Demons in November 1936.No. 1 Squadron, ''Operations Record Book'' (1925–1946), p. 114 In January 1937, it relinquished its Bulldogs to No. 21 Squadron, which was to hold them until they could be transferred to the soon-to-be-formed [[No. 2 Squadron RAAF|No. 2 Squadron]].Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', p. 231 By the end of February, No. 1 Squadron's strength was 12 Demons and one Moth, 11 officers and 108 airmen.No. 1 Squadron, ''Operations Record Book'' (1925–1946), p. 121 The unit was redesignated No. 1 (Bomber) Squadron in August 1937. Towards the end of the year, it was plagued by several Demon accidents, resulting in a series of inquiries and a review of RAAF procedures in 1938 by Marshal of the RAF [[Edward Leonard Ellington|Sir Edward Ellington]]; the so-called Ellington Report and its criticism of air safety standards led to the removal of Air Vice-Marshal Richard Williams from his position as Chief of the Air Staff, which he had held since the formation of the Air Force.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 114–118, 344–348 No. 1 Squadron received the RAAF's first three [[CAC Wirraway]]s on 10 July 1939.No. 1 Squadron, ''Operations Record Book'' (1925–1946), p. 162 As the likelihood of war increased, the squadron's role was altered to incorporate reconnaissance as well as bombing, resulting in the transfer out of all Demons and Wirraways and the transfer in from other units of nine [[Avro Anson]]s on 28–29 August 1939; at the end of the month its personnel comprised nine officers and 122 airmen.No. 1 Squadron, ''Operations Record Book'' (1925–1946), p. 163 ===World War II=== [[File:RAAF Hudson over Sydney Heads (AWM photo 128042).jpg|left|thumb|upright=1.2|alt=Twin-engined twin-tailed military monoplane in flight, side-on|Lockheed Hudson of No. 1 Squadron, c. 1940]] Following the [[Military history of Australia during World War II|outbreak of World War II]], No. 1 Squadron's Ansons were tasked with maritime patrol and convoy escort duties.Eather, ''Flying Squadrons'', pp. 19–21 In 1940, the squadron became the RAAF's inaugural [[Lockheed Hudson]] unit; it received its first Hudson on 30 March, and by the end of May had transferred out the last of its Ansons and was operating 11 of the new aircraft.Gillison, ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 141No. 1 Squadron, ''Operations Record Book'' (1925–1946), pp. 175–179 Deployed to [[British Malaya|Malaya]] to conduct maritime reconnaissance, No. 1 Squadron arrived at [[Sembawang Air Base|Sembawang]], Singapore, on 4 July 1940.RAAF Historical Section, ''Bomber Units'', pp. 3–4 It relocated to [[Kota Bharu]], near the Malaya–Thailand border, in August 1941.Gillison, ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 198 Two days before the [[Malayan Campaign|attack on Malaya]], its Hudsons spotted the Japanese invasion fleet but, given uncertainty about the ships' destination and instructions to avoid offensive operations until attacks were made against friendly territory, Air Chief Marshal [[Robert Brooke-Popham|Sir Robert Brooke-Popham]] did not allow the convoy to be bombed.Gillison, ''Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 200–201Shores et al., ''Bloody Shambles Volume One'', pp. 74–75 Shortly after midnight, local time, on the night of 7/8 December, the Japanese force started [[Battle of Kota Bharu|landing on the beaches at Kota Bharu]], close to the airfield, and from about 02:00, No. 1 Squadron launched a series of assaults on the Japanese forces, becoming the first aircraft to make an attack in the [[Pacific War]]. The Hudsons sank a Japanese transport ship, the [[IJN Awazisan Maru|IJN ''Awazisan Maru'']], and damaged two more transports, the ''Ayatosan Maru'' and ''Sakura Maru'', for the loss of two Hudsons, an hour before the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]].{{cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/raaf/organisation/info_on/units/1_sqn/ |title=No. 1 Squadron |publisher=Royal Australian Air Force |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211192008/http://www.defence.gov.au/raaf/organisation/info_on/units/1_sqn/ |archivedate=11 December 2007 |accessdate=21 February 2014}}Shores et al., ''Bloody Shambles Volume One'', pp. 80–83 By the end of the day, Japanese ground forces had advanced to the outskirts of the airfield, forcing the squadron's remaining airworthy aircraft to be evacuated to [[Kuantan]],Shores et al., ''Bloody Shambles Volume One'', pp. 95–96Gillison, ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 217 and from there back to Singapore.Gillison, ''Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 248–249 By Christmas Eve 1941, No. 1 Squadron had five serviceable aircraft. Together with [[No. 8 Squadron RAAF]], also equipped with Hudsons, it was tasked with maritime patrols to the east of Singapore.Gillison, ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 282 On 26 January 1942, two of the squadron's Hudsons spotted a Japanese convoy heading for [[Endau]], on the east coast of Malaya. It was decided to [[Battle off Endau|attack the convoy]] with all possible strength, including four Hudsons from No. 1 Squadron and five from No. 8 Squadron, together with obsolete [[Vickers Vildebeest]] and [[Fairey Albacore]] biplanes of [[No. 36 Squadron RAF|Nos. 36]] and [[No. 100 Squadron RAF|100 Squadrons RAF]], and with what little fighter escort could be found. The convoy was strongly defended by Japanese fighters, and although all nine Hudsons returned to Singapore, several were badly shot up. The rest of the strike force did not fare as well; 11 Vildebeests, two Albacores, two Hudsons (of [[No. 62 Squadron RAF]]) and three fighters were lost.Shores et al., ''Bloody Shambles Volume Two'', pp. 18–38Gillison, ''Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 344–346 By the end of the month, No. 1 Squadron had withdrawn to airfield P.2 on [[Sumatra]], along with several other Commonwealth units including No. 8 Squadron. It continued to attack Japanese bases in Malaya and convoys in the [[Dutch East Indies]], relocating to Semplak, [[Java]], in mid-February. At Semplak it took over the Hudsons of No. 8 Squadron and No. 62 Squadron RAF, giving it a strength of 25 aircraft; at one stage it was to be renumbered as an RAF squadron, but this never occurred.Johnston, ''Whispering Death'', pp. 120–125 Heavily outnumbered by Japanese air units, which raided Allied bases with impunity, No. 1 Squadron suffered heavy losses and was ordered to withdraw its four remaining Hudsons to Australia on 2 March 1942, disbanding soon after. Although 120 of the squadron's personnel were evacuated from Java, 160 men including the commanding officer, Wing Commander Davis, were unable to escape and were taken prisoner by the Japanese; less than half survived captivity.Johnston, ''Whispering Death'', pp. 125–126 No. 1 Squadron was re-formed with [[Bristol Beaufort]]s on 1 December 1943 at [[Menangle, New South Wales|Menangle]], New South Wales.RAAF Historical Section, ''Bomber Units'', p. 4 By March 1944 it had deployed to [[Gould Airfield|Gould]], Northern Territory, where it was controlled by [[No. 79 Wing RAAF|No. 79 Wing]] under [[North-Western Area Command (RAAF)|North-Western Area Command]].Odgers, ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 215 Its strength at the beginning of the month was some 350 officers and men, and 19 Beauforts.No. 1 Squadron, ''Operations Record Book'' (1925–1946), p. 235 The squadron commenced reconnaissance operations on 20 March, and undertook its first bombing mission on 4 April against [[Lautém District|Lautem]], East Timor. It attacked other targets in [[Timor]] during May, losing two aircraft.Odgers, ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 228, 231 Having undertaken 82 [[sortie]]s in July, the Beauforts concentrated on maritime reconnaissance from August, using air-to-surface radar during operations from Gould and [[Gove Airport|Gove]].Odgers, ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 244 After re-equipping with [[De Havilland Mosquito|Mosquito]] fighter-bombers at [[Kingaroy]], Queensland, in January 1945, the squadron deployed to [[Morotai]] in May and then [[Crown colony of Labuan|Labuan Island]] in June–July. Now part of [[No. 86 Wing RAAF|No. 86 (Attack) Wing]], it flew only a few missions before the end of the war, losing one Mosquito.Johnston, ''Whispering Death'', pp. 417–418 No. 1 Squadron returned to Australia in December 1945 and was disbanded at [[Narromine]], New South Wales, on 7 August 1946. ===Malayan Emergency=== [[File:RAAFAvroLincolnMalaya1950.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|Avro Lincoln of No. 1 Squadron dropping {{convert|500|lb|kg|adj=on}} bombs on communist targets during the Malayan Emergency, c. 1950|alt=Four-engined military aircraft in flight]] No. 1 Squadron was re-formed as a heavy bomber unit on 23 February 1948, when [[No. 12 Squadron RAAF|No. 12 Squadron]] was re-designated. Operating [[Avro Lincoln]]s, it was based at [[RAAF Base Amberley|RAAF Station Amberley]], Queensland, where it formed part of [[No. 82 Wing RAAF|No. 82 (Bomber) Wing]].{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/aircraft/series2/A73.htm |title=Avro Lincoln|publisher=[[RAAF Museum]]|accessdate=12 March 2014}} The wing's aircraft were serviced by [[No. 482 Squadron RAAF|No. 482 (Maintenance) Squadron]].RAAF Historical Section, ''Maintenance Units'', p. 66 From July 1950 to July 1958—for the first two-and-a-half years under the auspices of [[No. 90 Wing RAAF|No. 90 (Composite) Wing]]—it was based in Singapore, flying missions against communist guerrillas during the [[Malayan Emergency]].{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=196|title=No 90 Wing formed at Singapore| publisher =Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=12 March 2014}} Tasked by [[Far East Air Force (Royal Air Force)|RAF Air Headquarters Malaya]], the Lincolns generally conducted [[area bombing]] missions, as well as strikes against pinpoint targets. They operated singly and in formations, sometimes in concert with RAF bombers, and often strafed targets with their machine guns and 20 mm cannon after dropping ordnance. The Lincolns were considered well suited to the campaign, owing to their range and ability to fly at low speeds to search for targets, as well as their firepower and heavy bomb load.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 244, 247–248 Not having to contend with [[Anti-aircraft warfare|anti-aircraft fire]], they flew mainly by day, but No. 1 Squadron also operated by night, the only Commonwealth unit to do so. The squadron carried out its own day-to-day maintenance in Malaya; the Lincolns were rotated back to Australia for major work.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article52812622 |title=RAAF wing takes over a new important job |newspaper=[[The Examiner (Tasmania)|''The Examiner'']] |date=20 April 1951 |accessdate= 26 April 2014 |page=2 |publisher=}} Its original complement of six aircraft was increased to eight after the British [[Air Ministry]] requested in February 1951 that Australia augment its bomber force to partly offset the imminent withdrawal of the RAF's Lincolns to [[RAF Bomber Command|Bomber Command]] in Europe.Dennis; Grey, ''Emergency and Confrontation'', pp. 37–38 The squadron was awarded the [[Gloucester Cup]] for proficiency in 1950–51 and 1954–55.Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', p. 61 It suffered no casualties during the campaign but two of its aircraft were written off: one that overshot the landing strip at Tengah in November 1951, and another that crashed into the sea off [[Johore]] after striking trees on takeoff in January 1957.Wilson, ''Lincoln, Canberra and F-111 in Australian Service'', p. 67 Although the original purpose of the bombing campaign in Malaya was to kill as many insurgents as possible, the impracticality of achieving this in operations over dense jungle resulted in a shift towards harassing and demoralising the communists, driving them out of their bases and into areas held by Commonwealth ground troops. Operation Kingly Pile, which involved two sorties by No. 1 Squadron and one by [[English Electric Canberra]] jet bombers of [[No. 12 Squadron RAF]] on 21 February 1956, was considered the most successful of the more than 4,000 missions conducted by the Lincolns, killing at least 14 communist troops.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=409|title=Lincolns made best strike in Malayan Emergency|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=1 February 2014}}Coulthard-Clark, ''The Encyclopaedia of Australia's Battles'', p. 270 By the time it was withdrawn to Australia in July 1958, the squadron had dropped over 14,000 tonnes of bombs—85 per cent of the total delivered by Commonwealth forces during the Emergency.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=336|title=No 1 Squadron returned from Malaya| publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=15 April 2013}}Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', p. 71 Its service was recognised with the presentation of a [[Colours, standards and guidons|Squadron Standard]] by the Commander-in-Chief [[Far East Air Force (Royal Air Force)|Far East Air Force]], Air Marshal [[Percy Bernard, 5th Earl of Bandon|The Earl of Brandon]].Wilson, ''Lincoln, Canberra and F-111 in Australian Service'', p. 63 Until 2014, the Malayan Emergency had marked the last occasion that the unit took part in combat operations.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Air-Combat-Group/No.-82-Wing/No.-1-Squadron/?RAAF-LGjodmvBnUG6tbsKAUbGu4lNy07+Rf7x|title=No. 1 Squadron operations|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=6 April 2014}} ===Jet era=== [[File:English Electric Canberra bomber in RAAF livery at the 1964 Richmond Air Show, NSW.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|English Electric Canberra of the RAAF, 1964|alt=Side view of twin-jet, straight-winged aircraft parked on airfield]] No. 1 Squadron re-equipped with Canberra Mk.20s after returning to Australia. The RAAF's first jet bomber, the Canberra was subsonic but had long range and was highly manoeuvrable. It had been procured partly for its capacity to deliver [[nuclear weapon]]s, an ordnance option the government seriously contemplated but never acquired. Initially the Canberra's envisaged mission profile was medium-to-high-altitude area bombing but its primitive bombsight and light load made this a dubious proposition, and by mid-1961 crews were training in low-level army cooperation tactics.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 363–369{{cite journal|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Publications/Details/568/220-The-RAAFs-Strike-Capability-Part-II-Development-19452014.aspx#.U3TSPhCSySo|title=The RAAF's Strike Capability Part II: Development 1945–2014|work=Pathfinder|date=April 2014|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=16 May 2014}} No. 1 Squadron was awarded successive Gloucester Cups for its proficiency in 1959–60 and 1960–61.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article103082243 |title=Cup award to jet squadron |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |date=31 July 1961 |accessdate=5 September 2014 |page=2 }} As of January 1962, its strength was eight aircraft and 53 personnel, including 18 officers.No. 1 Squadron, ''Operations Record Book'' (1961–1988), p. 5 The unit effectively ceased operations in 1968, to begin converting to the [[General Dynamics F-111C]] supersonic bomber, which was expected to enter service soon afterwards.Lax, ''From Controversy to Cutting Edge'', p. 59 Already controversial owing to its escalating cost, the F-111 program was heavily delayed by airworthiness concerns related to its [[Variable-sweep wing|swing-wing]] technology.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 380–384 In September 1970, as an interim measure while awaiting delivery of the F-111, No. 1 Squadron relinquished its Canberras for leased [[McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II|McDonnell Douglas F-4E Phantoms]], which it operated until June 1973.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/aircraft/series2/A84.htm |title=Canberra|publisher=RAAF Museum|accessdate=12 March 2014}}Wilson, ''Lincoln, Canberra and F-111 in Australian Service'', p. 104Wilson, ''Phantom, Hornet and Skyhawk in Australian Service'', pp. 41, 56 Although the Phantom had a multi-role capability, the RAAF employed it as a strike aircraft to maintain compatibility with the proposed F-111 mission profile.Wilson, ''Phantom, Hornet and Skyhawk in Australian Service'', p. 42 One of No. 1 Squadron's Phantoms was lost with its crew of two in June 1971, the only fatalities and hull loss of the 24 aircraft leased to the RAAF.Wilson, ''Phantom, Hornet and Skyhawk in Australian Service'', p. 55 Though not as sophisticated an aircraft as the F-111, the Phantom was a significant advance over the Canberra, and well regarded by its Australian crews.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 387–388 [[File:RAAF Phantom Finney.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|F-4E Phantoms of the RAAF, 1971|alt=Two military jet fighters painted in camouflage livery parked in front of a large white building]] No. 82 Wing accepted its first F-111Cs in June 1973.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 282 The [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]], Air Marshal [[Charles Read (RAAF officer)|Charles Read]], ordered that the new aircraft be flown with great caution initially, well within operational limits, to minimise the possibility of further damage to its reputation through early attrition.Lax, ''From Controversy to Cutting Edge'', p. 121 No. 1 Squadron was assigned 12 of the initial 24 aircraft delivered. It was No. 82 Wing's lead strike force, while No. 6 Squadron was primarily tasked with [[Operational conversion unit|crew conversion training]].Wilson, ''Lincoln, Canberra and F-111 in Australian Service'', p. 160Eather, ''Flying Squadrons'', p. 35 The wing employed a centralised servicing regime, whereby all aircraft and maintenance personnel were held by No. 482 Squadron, which released the F-111s in line with Nos. 1 and 6 Squadrons' joint flying program.Lax, ''From Controversy to Cutting Edge'', p. 123 In February 1981, responsibility for operating-level servicing of the F-111s was transferred to the flying squadrons, which for the first time took direct control of their F-111s.RAAF Historical Section, ''Maintenance Units'', p. 68Lax, ''From Controversy to Cutting Edge'', p. 127 No. 482 Squadron continued to provide intermediate-level servicing, while major upgrades and complex maintenance were carried out by [[No. 3 Aircraft Depot RAAF|No. 3 Aircraft Depot]].Wilson, ''Lincoln, Canberra and F-111'', p. 160Lax, ''From Controversy to Cutting Edge'', p. 195 These two organisations merged in 1992 to form No. 501 Wing, which handed over heavy maintenance of the F-111 to [[Boeing Australia]] in 2001.Lax, ''From Controversy to Cutting Edge'', pp. 196, 222–223 Between 1977 and 1993, the RAAF lost seven F-111Cs in crashes.Lax, ''From Controversy to Cutting Edge'', p. 135 Three of the accidents involved aircraft flown by No. 1 Squadron: in August 1979, January 1986 and September 1993, the last two killing both crew members.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article110577558 |title=Crew escapes failing F111 |newspaper=The Canberra Times |date=25 August 1979 |accessdate=6 April 2014 |page=1 }}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article122423624 |title=Two die in F111 crash |newspaper=The Canberra Times |date=30 January 1986 |accessdate=6 April 2014 |page=1 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/1773434/honouring-crash-victims/|title=Honouring crash victims|newspaper=[[Northern Daily Leader|The Northern Daily Leader]]|date=13 September 2013|accessdate=6 April 2014}} In July 1996, No. 1 Squadron took responsibility for aerial reconnaissance using specially modified RF-111Cs previously operated by No. 6 Squadron.Lax, ''From Controversy to Cutting Edge'', pp. 141–142 This gave No. 1 Squadron five mission types: land strike, maritime strike, close air support, long-range air defence, and reconnaissance.{{cite magazine|last=Armstrong|first=John|title=Aussie F-111s|magazine=Air Force Today|pages=35–37|date=February 1997}} In May 1999 the unit was again awarded the Gloucester Cup for proficiency.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4510/features/feature03.htm|title=Notable dates in the history of the F-111|magazine=Air Force|date=19 June 2002|accessdate=5 September 2014}} [[File:Australian F-111s.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|F-111s of No. 1 Squadron, February 2006|alt=High front view of four swing-wing jet aircraft in flight]] Along with its revolutionary variable-sweep wings, the F-111 was equipped with [[terrain-following radar]] and an escape module that allowed the entire cockpit to be jettisoned in an emergency, instead of individual ejection seats.Lax, ''From Controversy to Cutting Edge'', p. 45 Its top speed was [[Mach number|Mach]] 2.5 and its [[combat radius]] gave it the capability of reaching targets in Indonesia from bases in northern Australia.Lax, ''From Controversy to Cutting Edge'', p. 110Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 58 Upon delivery in 1973 it was fitted with analogue [[avionics]] and could only drop [[unguided bomb|unguided ("dumb") bombs]]. In its 37 years of service with the RAAF the type went through several upgrades, including the [[Pave Tack]] infra-red and laser-guided precision weapons targeting system, [[Harpoon (missile)|Harpoon]] anti-shipping missiles, and advanced digital avionics.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/aircraft/series3/A8.htm |title=General Dynamics F-111|publisher= RAAF Museum|accessdate= 28 March 2011}} Alan Stephens, in the official history of the post-war Air Force, described the F-111 as "the region's pre-eminent strike aircraft" and the RAAF's most important acquisition.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 393–394 The closest they came to being used in anger, however, was during Australian-led [[INTERFET]] operations in [[East Timor]] commencing in September 1999. Both F-111 squadrons were deployed to [[RAAF Base Tindal]], Northern Territory, to support the international forces in case of action by the Indonesian military, and remained there until December; six of No. 1 Squadron's aircraft and approximately 100 personnel were involved. From 20 September, when INTERFET forces began to arrive in East Timor, the F-111s were maintained at a high level of readiness to conduct reconnaissance flights or air strikes if the situation deteriorated. As it happened, INTERFET did not encounter significant resistance, and F-111 operations were limited to reconnaissance by RF-111Cs from 5 November through 9 December.Wilson, ''Warden to Tanager'', pp. 32–34 [[File:RAAF Super Hornet arrival1.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|F/A-18F Super Hornet of No. 1 Squadron on arrival at RAAF Base Amberley, 26 March 2010|alt= Twin-finned military jet on an airfield, with a ground crewman in an orange vest in the foreground]] In 2007, the Australian government decided to retire the F-111s by 2010, and acquire 24 [[Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet|Boeing F/A-18F Super Hornets]] as an interim replacement, pending the arrival of the [[Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II|Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning]] then being developed.{{cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/media/DepartmentalTpl.cfm?CurrentId=6619|title=Super Hornet acquisition contract signed|publisher=[[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence]] |date=3 May 2007| accessdate= 16 August 2012}}{{cite news|last=Smiles|first=Sarah|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/alp-to-stick-with-super-hornet-buy/2008/03/17/1205602291258.html|title=ALP to stick with Super Hornet buy|work=[[The Age]]|date=18 March 2008|accessdate= 16 August 2012}} The F-111 fleet was considered to be at risk due to fatigue, and too expensive to operate as each aircraft required 180 hours of maintenance for every hour of flying time.Lax, ''From Controversy to Cutting Edge'', pp. 234–235{{cite news|last=McPhedran|first=Ian|author-link=Ian McPhedran|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/f-111-the-raafs-white-elephant-in-the-sky/story-e6freuy9-1225757243738|title=F-111 – the RAAF's white elephant in the sky|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=3 August 2009|accessdate=16 August 2012}} No. 1 Squadron ceased operating the F-111 in January 2009, in preparation for converting to the Super Hornet.McPhedran, ''Air Force Today'', p. 352 Former F-111 aircrew, familiar with side-by-side seating and a different performance envelope, found conversion more challenging than pilots experienced in the RAAF's [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet]] fighters, which shared many characteristics with the newer model.McPhedran, ''Air Force'', pp. 356–357 No. 1 Squadron re-equipped between 26 March 2010 and 21 October 2011, making it the first Australian unit, and the first squadron outside the United States, to fly the Super Hornet. It became operational with its new aircraft on 8 December 2011.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=607|title=Arrival of first Super Hornets|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=8 April 2014}} The multi-role Super Hornet allowed No. 1 Squadron to augment its previous offensive strike role with an air-to-air combat function.{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?xml=defencenews_airforce.xml&iid=43384&startpage=40|last=Curran|first=Aaron|title=Nothing like a little Pig rivalry|magazine=Air Force|page=9|date=9 December 2010|accessdate=30 April 2014}} The RAAF attained [[full operational capability]] with the Super Hornet in December 2012.{{cite news|title=RAAF headed back to Iraq|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2014/09/raaf-headed-back-to-iraq/|accessdate=15 September 2014|newspaper=Australian Aviation|date=15 September 2014}} On 14 September 2014, the Federal government committed to deploying up to eight Super Hornets of No. 1 Squadron to [[Al Minhad Air Base]] in the United Arab Emirates, as part of the [[Operation Okra|Australian Air Task Group]] joining the [[2014 military intervention against the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|coalition]] against [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL) forces in Iraq. Aircraft from the squadron conducted their first mission over Iraq on 5 October, and their first strike four days later.{{cite news|last=Nicholson|first=Brendann|title=RAAF flies first combat mission in Iraq|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/raaf-flies-first-combat-mission-in-iraq/story-fn59niix-1227080986504|accessdate=6 October 2014|newspaper=[[The Australian]]|date=6 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2014/10/raaf-conducts-first-iraq-airstrikes/|title=RAAF conducts first Iraq airstrikes|work=Australian Aviation|date= 9 October 2014|accessdate=16 October 2014}} According to the [[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence]], as of 20 December 2014 the Super Hornets had flown over 180 sorties, dropped 113 weapons, and destroyed 36 ISIL targets, damaging another six.{{cite web|url=http://news.defence.gov.au/2014/12/20/australian-operations-in-iraq-continue-to-press-isil/|title=Australian operations in Iraq continue to press ISIL|publisher=Department of Defence |date=20 December 2014| accessdate= 8 January 2015}} In March 2015, having flown almost 3,000 hours in over 400 missions, the detachment was replaced by six F/A-18As from [[No. 75 Squadron RAAF|No. 75 Squadron]].{{cite magazine|title=Air Task Group Deploys|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?iid=114640#folio=8|accessdate=10 March 2015|magazine=Air Force|date=12 March 2015|page=8}}{{cite magazine|title=RAAF's 75SQN takes over Okra operations|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2015/03/raafs-75sqn-takes-over-okra-operations/|accessdate=30 March 2015|magazine=Australian Aviation|date=30 March 2015}} ==Future== In May 2013, the Federal government announced plans to purchase 12 [[Boeing EA-18G Growler]]s to supplement the Super Hornet fleet.{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?iid=76842&xml=defencenews_airforce.xml&startpage=2|last=Bree|first=Max|title=A formidable force|magazine=Air Force|page=2|date=9 May 2013|accessdate= 29 November 2013}} No. 6 Squadron is expected to begin taking delivery of the Growlers in 2017, at which point its Super Hornets will be transferred to No. 1 Squadron.{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?startpage=2&iid=84161#folio=2|last=Popp|first=Tony|title=Growler one step closer|magazine=Air Force|page=3|date=21 November 2013|accessdate=18 November 2013}} In April 2014, the government announced the purchase of 58 F-35s in addition to 14 already ordered, for the express purpose of replacing the 71 "classic" Hornets of Nos. 3, 75 and [[No. 77 Squadron RAAF|77 Squadrons]] and [[No. 2 Operational Conversion Unit RAAF|No. 2 Operational Conversion Unit]].{{cite web|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2014/04/pm-confirms-raaf-order-for-58-f-35as/|title=PM confirms RAAF order for 58 F-35As|work=Australian Aviation|date= 23 April 2014|accessdate=26 April 2014}} A government decision on whether to purchase a further 28 F-35s, to be based at Amberley, will depend on how long the Super Hornets are to be retained.{{cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/dmo/about/domains/nacc.cfm|title=New air combat capability|publisher=[[Defence Materiel Organisation]]|accessdate=8 May 2014}} According to ''[[Australian Aviation (magazine)|Australian Aviation]]'', continuing delays to the F-35 program have increased the likelihood that the Super Hornets of Nos. 1 and 6 Squadrons will, rather than being disposed of early as originally planned, continue to be operated by the RAAF for their full service life of over 20 years. ==Aircraft operated== {{Div col|cols=3}} *[[Royal Aircraft Factory B.E.2|Royal Aircraft Factory B.E.2/B.E.12]] (1916–18) *[[Martinsyde G.100|Martinsyde G.100/G.102]] (1916–18) *[[Royal Aircraft Factory R.E.8]] (1917–18) *[[Bristol F.2 Fighter]] (1917–19) *[[Airco DH.9]]/[[Airco DH.9A|DH.9A]] (1925–29) *[[Royal Aircraft Factory S.E.5]] (1925–28) *[[Westland Wapiti]] (1929–36) *[[Hawker Demon]] (1935–39) *[[Bristol Bulldog]] (1935–37) *[[Avro Anson]] (1939–40) *[[Lockheed Hudson]] (1940–42)
